00024 #ifndef _NIF_PROPERTY_H_
00025 #define _NIF_PROPERTY_H_
00026 
00027 #include "controlled.hpp"
00028 
00029 namespace Nif
00030 {
00031 
00032 class Property : public Named
00033 {
00034 public:
00035   // The meaning of these depends on the actual property type.
00036   int flags;
00037 
00038   void read(NIFFile *nif)
00039   {
00040     Named::read(nif);
00041     flags = nif->getShort();
00042   }
00043 };
00044 
00045 class NiTexturingProperty : public Property
00046 {
00047 public:
00048   // A sub-texture
00049   struct Texture
00050   {
00051     /* Clamp mode
00052        0 - clampS clampT
00053        1 - clampS wrapT
00054        2 - wrapS clampT
00055        3 - wrapS wrapT
00056     */
00057 
00058     /* Filter:
00059        0 - nearest
00060        1 - bilinear
00061        2 - trilinear
00062        3, 4, 5 - who knows
00063     */
00064     bool inUse;
00065     NiSourceTexturePtr texture;
00066 
00067     int clamp, set, filter;
00068     short unknown2;
00069 
00070     void read(NIFFile *nif)
00071     {
00072       inUse = !!nif->getInt();
00073       if(!inUse) return;
00074 
00075       texture.read(nif);
00076       clamp = nif->getInt();
00077       filter = nif->getInt();
00078       set = nif->getInt();
00079 
00080       // I have no idea, but I think these are actually two
00081       // PS2-specific shorts (ps2L and ps2K), followed by an unknown
00082       // short.
00083       nif->skip(6);
00084     }
00085   };
00086 
00087   /* Apply mode:
00088      0 - replace
00089      1 - decal
00090      2 - modulate
00091      3 - hilight  // These two are for PS2 only?
00092      4 - hilight2
00093   */
00094   int apply;
00095 
00096   /*
00097    * The textures in this list are as follows:
00098    *
00099    * 0 - Base texture
00100    * 1 - Dark texture
00101    * 2 - Detail texture
00102    * 3 - Gloss texture (never used?)
00103    * 4 - Glow texture
00104    * 5 - Bump map texture
00105    * 6 - Decal texture
00106    */
00107   Texture textures[7];
00108 
00109   void read(NIFFile *nif)
00110   {
00111     Property::read(nif);
00112     apply = nif->getInt();
00113 
00114     // Unknown, always 7. Probably the number of textures to read
00115     // below
00116     nif->getInt();
00117 
00118     textures[0].read(nif); // Base
00119     textures[1].read(nif); // Dark
00120     textures[2].read(nif); // Detail
00121     textures[3].read(nif); // Gloss (never present)
00122     textures[4].read(nif); // Glow
00123     textures[5].read(nif); // Bump map
00124     if(textures[5].inUse)
00125       {
00126         // Ignore these at the moment
00127         /*float lumaScale =*/ nif->getFloat();
00128         /*float lumaOffset =*/ nif->getFloat();
00129         /*const Vector4 *lumaMatrix =*/ nif->getVector4();
00130       }
00131     textures[6].read(nif); // Decal
00132   }
00133 };
00134 
00135 // These contain no other data than the 'flags' field in Property
00136 typedef Property NiShadeProperty;
00137 typedef Property NiDitherProperty;
00138 typedef Property NiZBufferProperty;
00139 typedef Property NiSpecularProperty;
00140 typedef Property NiWireframeProperty;
00141 
00142 // The rest are all struct-based
00143 template <typename Struct>
00144 struct StructPropT : Property
00145 {
00146   const Struct* data;
00147 
00148   void read(NIFFile *nif)
00149   {
00150     Property::read(nif);
00151     data = nif->getPtr<Struct>();
00152   }
00153 };
00154 
00155 struct S_MaterialProperty
00156 {
00157   // The vector components are R,G,B
00158   Vector ambient, diffuse, specular, emissive;
00159   float glossiness, alpha;
00160 };
00161 
00162 struct S_VertexColorProperty
00163 {
00164   /* Vertex mode:
00165      0 - source ignore
00166      1 - source emmisive
00167      2 - source amb diff
00168 
00169      Lighting mode
00170      0 - lighting emmisive
00171      1 - lighting emmisive ambient/diffuse
00172   */
00173   int vertmode, lightmode;
00174 };
00175 
00176 struct S_AlphaProperty
00177 {
00178   /*
00179     In NiAlphaProperty, the flags have the following meaning:
00180 
00181     Bit 0 : alpha blending enable
00182     Bits 1-4 : source blend mode
00183     Bits 5-8 : destination blend mode
00184     Bit 9 : alpha test enable
00185     Bit 10-12 : alpha test mode
00186     Bit 13 : no sorter flag ( disables triangle sorting )
00187 
00188     blend modes (glBlendFunc):
00189     0000 GL_ONE
00190     0001 GL_ZERO
00191     0010 GL_SRC_COLOR
00192     0011 GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_COLOR
00193     0100 GL_DST_COLOR
00194     0101 GL_ONE_MINUS_DST_COLOR
00195     0110 GL_SRC_ALPHA
00196     0111 GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA
00197     1000 GL_DST_ALPHA
00198     1001 GL_ONE_MINUS_DST_ALPHA
00199     1010 GL_SRC_ALPHA_SATURATE
00200 
00201     test modes (glAlphaFunc):
00202     000 GL_ALWAYS
00203     001 GL_LESS
00204     010 GL_EQUAL
00205     011 GL_LEQUAL
00206     100 GL_GREATER
00207     101 GL_NOTEQUAL
00208     110 GL_GEQUAL
00209     111 GL_NEVER
00210 
00211     Taken from:
00212     http://niftools.sourceforge.net/doc/nif/NiAlphaProperty.html
00213 
00214     Right now we only use standard alpha blending (see the Ogre code
00215     that sets it up) and it appears that this is the only blending
00216     used in the original game. Bloodmoon (along with several mods) do
00217     however use other settings, such as discarding pixel values with
00218     alpha < 1.0. This is faster because we don't have to mess with the
00219     depth stuff like we did for blending. And OGRE has settings for
00220     this too.
00221   */
00222 
00223   // Tested against when certain flags are set (see above.)
00224   unsigned char threshold;
00225 };
00226 
00227 typedef StructPropT<S_AlphaProperty> NiAlphaProperty;
00228 typedef StructPropT<S_MaterialProperty> NiMaterialProperty;
00229 typedef StructPropT<S_VertexColorProperty> NiVertexColorProperty;
00230 
00231 } // Namespace
00232 #endif
